utterances: The numbers go like this: very few women - just a quarter of those surveyed - said they were looking for long-term relationships, and nearly twice as many black men said they were looking to go long-term.
(unintelligible)
You know they're not.
(LAUGHTER)
Jerry Dworak is the CEO of Montana Health Co-Op.
They have been very good on good government reform.
We've had a lot of ethical issues and corruption issues in the Democratic Party in the legislative and executive and also in local government.
And Republicans have pitched themselves as reformers, and I think that has played well for them.
Are there any Republican leaders in Oklahoma who have a chance at national prominence now?
Yes, Tom Coburn.
Dr. Tom Coburn is the junior senator from Oklahoma, and he is highly acceptable to social conservatives and agrees with their issues.
But if you look at his career and reputation, he has built it on issues of governmental ethics and integrity and fiscal accountability.
But in addition to that, despite being a staunch conservative, he has the ability to make friends across the aisle.
Tom Coburn would count among those people he respects and can get along with, Senator Russ Feingold from Wisconsin, but also the incoming president of the United States, Barack Obama.
Of all the Republicans out there, Coburn can stand as an ethical and budgetary guidepost, yet also go toe to toe with the White House and also negotiate with them.
And I believe that Tom Coburn will enjoy substantial prominence in the coming years in the GOP, should he choose to step forward and take that leadership role.
Keith Gaddie, professor of political science at the University of Oklahoma, thanks so much.
Thank you, sir.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
This month, we've sent NPR reporters on the road crossing the country to find out how Americans feel about the government, and you can visit our Web site, npr.org, to follow their paths.
NPR's Andrea Seabrook is in Iowa.
It's a state where presidential politics makes some there feel more in tune with Washington.
I'm standing across the street from American Dream Machines.
It's a classic car dealership.
Inside the plate glass windows, I can see a '65 Mustang, a midnight blue Corvette Stingray and a silver Ferrari.
But what's notable about this place is actually what I don't see.
Up until last year, this building was presidential hopeful John Kerry's Iowa headquarters.
And what's not here now are national news correspondents, satellite trucks, political staff or adoring volunteers; just a Des Moines city street and a car dealership.
And we had Wolf Blitzer in our of our private rooms, as well as Senator Kennedy.
We even have...
That's Sheri Osborn.
She's a bartender at 801 Steak & Chop House, the fanciest restaurant in town.
Chris Matthews came in every night.
He usually sat at that first booth in the bar.
Thought this place echoes with the chatter of politicos and journalists once every four years, today it's pretty deserted.
Still, you can't really talk Iowa politics without coming here, what political journalist David Yepsen calls the birthplace of conventional wisdom.
This place in caucus time becomes a real watering hole for candidates, for their staffs, for media people on expense accounts to come and relax.
Iowans all over benefit from these high-rollers who blow through on election years.
But what about the political off-season, when the caucuses are a full two and a half years away?
Yepsen says there is no real off-season.
There are candidates who are coming in here.
Evan Bayh was in here last week.
John Edwards is coming in in a couple weeks.
Newt Gingrich is in here at the end of the week.
So there's always somebody doing something out there that has something to do with presidential politics.
And, says Yepsen, it's not just politics that Iowans care about; it's policy, it's what the government does in the years after the caucuses.
And he says Iowans understand that they have a huge impact on who gets to lead the country.
There are some who--like Jimmy Carter, who win here and go all the way to the White House.
There are others like John Kerry, who win here and get a nomination.
There are many others who don't do well here and they're done.
So I think Iowans understand that these caucuses have a big impact on who leads their government, and that's why they pay attention to it.
But does living with the politics make Iowans feel differently about the government?
Out on the sidewalk in front of the local restaurant Spaghetti Works, Ted Linquist(ph) says politics is a flash in the pan; government moves much more slowly.
Well, I think the government is like a big ship.
You know, it doesn't turn very fast, but I think with good leadership and over a period of years, it helps turn things around.
And several people, like Frank Burnett(ph), say it's not all fun and excitement when, in the run-up to the caucuses, all the politicos and their accompanying circus are in town.
Good Lord, they're all over the place.
They're like lemmings or vermin; I'm not sure which.
They're--you can't move without tripping over them.
It's kind of crazy.
I think about a month and a half of that's plenty.
And so while Iowa may be the center of the political universe every four years, its citizens aren't that much different from many other Americans.
They tolerate politics and hope for good government.
Andrea Seabrook, NPR News, Des Moines, Iowa.
Many of those who support the deep cuts to Medicaid called for in the Republican health care bills say it's simply too expensive.
But some health insurers say if Medicaid shrinks, that could lead to higher costs for everyone.
Eric Whitney reports from Montana, one of the last states to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act.

The Republicans who make up two-thirds of Montana's congressional delegation say a big reason they want to repeal the current health care law is because it's causing health insurance markets to, quote, ""collapse."" But the insurance companies that sell policies here say that's not true in Montana.
And they're concerned about GOP repeal and replace plans.
I don't think that their plan is going to improve health care in the state of Montana.
Indeed, Cumulus runs Limbaugh's show on dozens of its own stations, and Dickey says his company intends to be in business with Limbaugh for quite some time.
But it wants to develop its own roster of stars.
Well, I think the quote was ""we eat our own cooking."" I think that was mine.
And we've got the governor's show on, give or take, 40 radio stations in 40 different cities out of the 120 we do business in.
On Monday, Huckabee had a pretty big get.
(SOUNDBITE OF RADIO SHOW, ""THE MIKE HUCKABEE SHOW"")
And we're very happy to have Gov.
Mitt Romney join me as our very first guest on ""The Mike Huckabee Show."" Gov.
Romney, welcome.
It's good to have you here.
Thanks, Mike.
Good to be with you, and congratulations on the new show.
Well, thank you.
There were other familiar figures, including Fox News commentator Dick Morris and Republican strategist Ed Rollins, both former Huckabee consultants.
But on that first show, there was also a ringer.
(SOUNDBITE OF RADIO SHOW, ""THE MIKE HUCKABEE SHOW"")
All right.
We're going to go to the phone lines.
And we've got a call from Mike in San Francisco.
Welcome to the ""The Mike Huckabee Show,"" Mike.
Well, governor, let me start by saying it's great to have a different opinion, and a different person on the radio.
And I'm very, very happy that you're doing this radio show.
Mike the caller was actually one of Huckabee's new bosses, Mike McVay, the senior vice president for programming at Cumulus.
McVay's call was revealed by the conservative publication the American Spectator, which blasted Huckabee as a RINO - a Republican in name only.
Huckabee says people mistake his civility for centrism.
Four years ago, when I ran for president, I told people that I'm a conservative, but I'm not mad at anybody over it.
And I'm not.
I'm a very happy guy.
And now we'll find out if Mike Huckabee's brand of conservatism will inspire enough Huckabeetniks to rival the audiences of Limbaugh's Dittoheads.
David Folkenflik, NPR News.
From feeding cattle to stealing cattle.
Cattle-rustling might seem like something out of the past, but it's still an issue in some parts of the country.
In Texas, ranchers are seeing an increase in stolen cows, even as the overall number of cattle shrinks.
From member station KUT in Austin, Mose Buchele brings us the story.
